abstractContent.text: Intervals and the events that occur in them are encoded as strings, elaborating on a conception of events as "intervals cum description ." Notions of satisfaction in interval temporal logics are formulated in terms of strings, and the possibility of computing these via finite-state machines/transducers is investigated.
This opens up temporal semantics to finite-state methods, with entailments that are decidable insofar as these can be reduced to inclusions between regular languages.

For the purposes of natural language semantics, however, it has been argued since at least) that intervals should replace points.

It is less clear (than in the case of LTL) how to view models as strings for intervals drawn (say) from the real line R, as in one of the more recent interval temporal logics proposed for English, the system T PL of (Pratt-).
But if we follow T PL in restricting our models to finite sets, we can encode satisfaction of a formula ψ in a set L(ψ) of strings str(A, I) representing models A and intervals I
